Name: John Davies

Address: Clynrelig, Llanwenog, Llanybyther.

Occupation, profession or business: Making rivetted boots (rounder) and operates Boot Finishing Machine. Also repairs occasionally.

Attested or not attested: Attested

Grounds: That the decision of the local tribunal has inflicted hardship upon me. The man whom I appeal for, with the aid of machines which he operates, makes three quarters of the quantity of new boots which I produce, and his absence will put me in a position that I shall be unable to execute the orders I have on hand. I have tried to obtain a substitute through the Labour Exchange but have failed. I appeal for a temporary certificate to be allowed to keep him for a month so that I can execute the orders on hand.

Signature of appellant: Evan Williams

Address of appellant: Llanwnen Llanybyther.

Occupation, profession or business: Boot Manufacturer

Why appellant acts for the man: Appeal made as man's employer

Description: Handwritten petition to Cardiganshire County Tribunal

Transcription: To the members of the Cardiganshire County Tribunal. Gentlemen, We the undersigned farmers in mid-Cardiganshire do earnestly appeal to you, on behalf of Mr. Daniel Jones, Fawnog, Gors-Goch Llanybyther for maintaining his valuable services to us by granting him total exemption from military service. We deem him indispensable to us, with regard to the fixing and repairing of Oil-engines, etc. We have bought Oil-engines off him in the course of the last few months, and his terms at the time of purchase were, that he was responsible for a twelve-month after to fixing, repairing, and seeing to the same. It is impossible for us to do these things ourselves, and the hiring of a mechanic for these jobs means the payment of an extra two or three guineas to him. Evan Walters, Lancwrn, Pontshaen, Llandysul. John Morgan. Rhydygweision, Cross Inn. I had an Oil-engine off him + not finish fixed. D.H.M. Evans, Stores and Mills Pontshaen.

Grounds: a, d, + f, g. I know not whether ploughman etc should come under g.

Nature of application: Absolute.

Tag: Beige R41/42: Page 1

Reasons: I am indispensable for carrying on the farm. My servant is already called up with the 15th Group of single men, leaving me the sole man on the farm. I am the ploughman and horseman and tiller of the soil. The farm as yet owing to the inclemency of the weather is unploughed and as I have made arrangements for breaking more land this year, owing to the call of the Board of Agriculture and the general need of the farm. I am in an exceptional position. I have had already sacrifice my business as a Cattle Dealer owing to my servant being called up, and have to devote all my time to my farm, for I will have to cultivate at least some fourteen acres now. I have no one to look after the horses or lend about in anything owing to the scarcity of labour, and If I was called up, the farm, since it is my own, would of necessity come to a standstill. I am sorry gentlemen, for I cannot undertake combatant services.

Signature: M. Ll. Williams.

Reason for decision of Local Tribunal: Some time ago, the Cardigan County Council, in reference to an appeal from the authorities at Seaford who suffers from shortage of labour, to construct military roads, kindly allows a certain number of their Roadmen to leave their District, and assist at Seaford. Amongst those allowed to go was the present applicant: which was the means of leaving certain parts of the main roads unattended, with the result that at a meeting of the Main Roads Committee for the Southern Division, a Complaint was made by one, or more very well known, and popular member present of the BAD conditions of the roads, and a request made for the return of some if not all the roadmen. The present applicant was one who returned to resume work on his portion of the road entrusted to him, which is sufficient evidence of the INDISPENSABILITY of this man's service, whose mileage has already being extended. It was also pointed out that Timber Haulage is carried over a portion of his road and with this heavy traffic requires a "man on the Spot." The Surveyor has also written to the applicant showing the need of his service as roadman and the hope that he would be allowed to remain to continue his good work. Moreover, this man's family has done Yeoman Service for their Country in the present Crisis, and have set a splendid example for others to copy, by having already send Three brothers of the applicant to uphold the honour of our Country. Description: Letter from W.J.Wallis-Jones relating to medical classification of David John Thomas, Glanraven, Llanwenog.

Transcription: [In pencil at head] Hear next meeting. Carmarthen. 16/12/ 1916. Dear Sir, Appeal Tribunal, Re. David John Thomas, Glanraven, Llanwenog. You will remember that I appeared in the above case at the Appeal Tribunal at Lampeter on the 1st. inst when, owing to circumstances detailed at the hearing, the Tribunal adjourned the case to enable the man to be again examined by the Medical Board but, notwithstanding repeat applications to the Cardiganshire Recruiting Officer (Major Mathias), he has been unable to obtain permission to go before the Medical Board again, and in letter from Major Mathias dated the 11th. ins. which is now before me, it is stated that it is not "admissable" for the man to have another medical examination, as he was passed Class "A" by the Carmarthen Medical Board in September last and that he (Major Mathias) holds the Medical History Sheet for that examination, and has informed the Military Representative. You will remember that it was stated that the man was given a "B" Class Card at Carmarthen, but the local Constable called about 3 days later and handed him an "A" Class Card signed by Major Mathias, in exchange for the one given him at Carmarthen. It was also stated to the Tribunal that on presenting himself for attestation under the Derby scheme at Lampeter, he was rejected by the examining officer Dr. Rowland. Under the circumstances I shall be glad if you will kindly let me know what course should now be taken, as I understand that they will not examine men from Cardiganshire at Carmarthen at all, and not even at Brecon without special authority. Yours faithfully, W.J.Wallis-Jones. Evan Evans, Esq. Clerk to the Cardiganshire Appeal Tribunal, Aberystwyth.

Reason for decision of Local Tribunal: A man's word is his bond - the Employer in this instance had two appeals down for hearing. It was decided to take both cases together, after all possible information has been obtained, and before the members of the Tribunal had considered the Evidence - "Major Williams remarked that if one of the appeals was disallowed he would not object to the decision in the other appeal". As it happens the decision arrived at was a Counterpart of Major William's remark and yet the Military think fit to appeal. Apart of a semblance of a pre arrangement between the Military and the Members, both cases were very carefully considered when it was disclosed that here was a man carrying on a very extensive Country trade - (documents produced). Catering for a large and scattered district. One who had already been depleted of the service of Three of his past employees. (One son) at different times, but was still persevering, and the fact that he has done so well in the past proves that he does NOT in the present appeal for the retention of some help, try to discount the necessity for more soldiers, for he proved conclusively before the Tribunal that it was utterly impossible for him to carry on alone. For in addition to his shop trade he is also the Postmaster for the district with a Telegraph and Money office attached. And the person appealed against by the Military is in sole charge of the Postal Department: and to deprive the Employer of this man will seriously interfere and dislocate the postal arrangement of this (and other) districts also and I believe, gentleman, you will all agree with me that we are pretty thin skinned if any interference is attempted or caused to our Correspondence. This as well as the fact that somebody must be retained to supply the public with their commodities helped us to be unanimous to grant "Conditional" Exemption in this case. Llew. O. Davies, Chairman. 02/11/1916

Transcription: Pensarn Cottage, Cwrt Newydd, Llanybyther 30/10/ 1916. To the Clerk of the County Tribunal, Dear Sir, I beg to inform you that my son Evan Thomas has this day been before the Army Medical Board at Carmarthen, and that he has been placed in Class C1 for service at home only. I do herewith enclose you the Classification Certificate. I should feel much obliged if you would kindly mention this fact to the Tribunal when his case will be before them on Thursday. May I express the hope that they will consider this fact an additional reason why they should accede to the request already made in the statement sent you last week. As my establishment has already been reduced as regards the number of employees far below my real requirements, I hope the Tribunal will see their way to grant me the service of my son. I maintain that he is doing work of national importance where he is now. I remain Sir, Yours Respectfully, John Thomas. To Evan Evans, Esq, County Clerk, Aberystwyth.

Transcription: Trebannau, Cellan, Lampeter 28/10/1916. Dear Sir John Dulais Davies, Lanlas, Cellan. I have engaged this man for next year and I shall be glad to know if I shall be allowed to keep him. I understand that the Appeal Tribunal has dismissed his application, and that his time is up on the 31st Oct. His services will not be required with his present employer next year, but I am informed that a farm servant is allowed to engage at another farm if the circumstances are similar. I farm 60 acres of highly cultivated land. I sow about 15 acres of corn and I have about three acres of green crop and potatoes. I milk seven cows and I keep not less than 15 other cattle. I have three horses in reguar work, and I generally have a few young horses. I have about 50 sheep, seven pigs and 1 breeding sow. I am a widower with two daughters, the elder is 18 years of age, the other is at school. I keep one servant girl. I have made every effort to get a man before military age, but I have entirely failed, and this is the only available man I can hear of free in the district. Before the war I was able to get casual labour, but this is now impossible. The present boy I have is leaving me to work on the railway. He will be of military age at the beginning of next year. I have only been farming for nine years, before that I lived in London but on account of ill health I was obliged to come to the country to live. I am able to do very little more than superintend and I cannot plough or do any hard work. If I cannot keep a servant man I shall be obliged to give up farming and as this man is the only one I can hear of, I trust the Tribunal will see the reasonableness of my application. My sales from the farm are far in excess of farms of its size and if necessary I shall be pleased

Transcription: Trebannau, Cellan, Lampeter. 30/10/1916. John Dulais Davies Dear Sir I am very much obliges for your letter of the 21st inst. and I note what you say that there is not much chance of the Tribunal agreeing to review the case unless strong new facts are placed before them. I do not know whether it would not be thought that inasmuch as the man changes his place that all the facts are new and that therefore the case might be reviewed. That HERE is an EXCEPTIONAL Case where evidence is forthcoming that the people on this holding thoroughly realize the Crisis of this Country, and nobly respond, by doubling their energy in the production of more food for man and beast.
